newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Yugo Hemofarm expands its Montenegrin business.
newsitem.headline: Yugo Hemofarm expands its Montenegrin business.

text.p: Yugoslav drug maker Hemofarm, expanding its operations in Montenegro, has started work on a 14.5 million dinar ($2.9 million) medical solution plant in Podgorica, Hemofarm press officer Gordana Velovan said on Tuesday.
"This is the second stage in our planned expansion in Montenegro," Velovan said.
Out of the total investment of 14.5 million dinars, Hemofarm of Vrsac in north-eastern Serbia provided 69.85 percent, Velovan said.
The Montenegrin mortgage bank Hipotekarna banka invested three million dinars, while the rest was provided by the Montenegrin Health Fund and the Montenegro Bank, she added.
According to Velovan, the company will first build a new boiler plant. Hemofarm will also remodel and equip production and storage areas.

Two years ago, Hemofarm launched its Montenegrin operations entering a joint venture with the Montenegrin Health Fund and the Montenegro Bank to create the first plant producing simple medical solutions in Podgorica.
Hemofarm appeared as a majority shareholder, owning 76 percent of the stake in the venture called Hemomont.
Hemomont began to produce eight varieties of eye drops, deficient in the Yugoslav market.
"Over last two years, the plant expanded its production to reach a three percent share in the total Hemofarm turnover," Velovan said.
Hemofarm is the second largest Yugoslav drug producer. Its nine month turnover exceeded 460 million dinars.
The Hemofarm concern comprises seven domestic and seven foreign companies. Foreign operations are based in Germany, Romania, China and the Bosnian Serb Republic.
